issues.description: Attribute naming inconsistency for Ride.shortCode: the problem statement (UML) names the attribute shortCode (char) and therefore students will likely implement a getter getShortCode(). The solution implementation instead names the field abbreviation and provides getAbbreviation(). This deviates from the UML/requirements and can confuse students (and automated tests) about the expected getter name and attribute identity.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the attribute name consistent across artifacts. Either rename the solution's field and getter to match the UML (private char shortCode; public char getShortCode()) or update the problem statement/UML to use 'abbreviation' and document the expected getter name. Aligning names will avoid student confusion and test mismatches.

issues.description: The UML/problem statement defines the Ride attribute as 'shortCode: char' (problem_statement.md line 23), but the solution implementation names the corresponding field 'abbreviation' with getter getAbbreviation() (solution_repository/src/de/tum/in/ase/Ride.java). Both represent the same conceptual entity (a single-character short identifier for a Ride) but are given different identifiers across artifacts. This mismatch can confuse students trying to map the UML specification to the provided/expected code (e.g., they may look for getShortCode() or a shortCode field when the solution uses 'abbreviation').
issues.suggested_fix: Make the identifier consistent across artifacts. Either (A) change the solution code to use the UML name: rename the field and constructor parameter to 'shortCode' and provide getShortCode(), or (B) update the UML/problem statement to use the name 'abbreviation' (and getAbbreviation()) so all artifacts use the same identifier. Prefer aligning code to the UML when the UML is the exercise specification.
